unnormalised: Delhi HC reserves order in hilarious 'Ghare Baire' IP case!
normalised: Delhi High Court reserves order in hilarious 'Ghare Baire' I-P case!

unnormalised: In a courtroom drama more captivating than a Bollywood potboiler, the Delhi High Court has reserved its order in a particularly spicy intellectual property case concerning the rights to a song used in a stage adaptation of Tagore’s ‘Ghare Baire.’ Sources say the arguments were so intense, Adv. Sharma nearly broke into song himself (thankfully, he didn't, or we would've had another case on our hands!).
normalised: In a courtroom drama more captivating than a Bollywood potboiler, the Delhi High Court has reserved its order in a particularly spicy intellectual property case concerning the rights to a song used in a stage adaptation of Tagore's 'Ghare Baire.' Sources say the arguments were so intense, Advocate Sharma nearly broke into song himself (thankfully, he didn't, or we would've had another case on our hands!).

unnormalised: Apparently, the original composer is claiming royalties due since, like, 2010 or something. The defence, meanwhile, argues fair use, citing the fact that Tagore himself probably wouldn't have minded a bit of artistic interpretation, especially if it gets the youth hooked on some good ol' Bengali culture. Seriously, imagine Tagore tweeting about copyright infringement!
normalised: Apparently, the original composer is claiming royalties due since, like, two thousand and ten or something. The defence, meanwhile, argues fair use, citing the fact that Tagore himself probably wouldn't have minded a bit of artistic interpretation, especially if it gets the youth hooked on some good old Bengali culture. Seriously, imagine Tagore tweeting about copyright infringement!

unnormalised: The judge, bless his soul, seemed particularly amused by the fact that the disputed song was, according to sources, “slightly off-key” in the stage adaptation. “So you’re telling me,” he reportedly quipped, “that the alleged infringement actually *improved* the original work? Fascinating!” One legal expert, speaking off the record, mentioned this could set a precedent for "unintentional artistic enhancement" under Section 52(1)(j) of the Copyright Act, 1957. Let's hope this ruling doesn’t inspire a wave of badly sung covers claiming copyright immunity!
normalised: The judge, bless his soul, seemed particularly amused by the fact that the disputed song was, according to sources, "slightly off-key" in the stage adaptation. "So you're telling me," he reportedly quipped, "that the alleged infringement actually *improved* the original work? Fascinating!" One legal expert, speaking off the record, mentioned this could set a precedent for "unintentional artistic enhancement" under Section fifty two (one) (j) of the Copyright Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty seven. Let's hope this ruling doesn't inspire a wave of badly sung covers claiming copyright immunity!

unnormalised: The court will announce its verdict on 01/12/2024, hopefully bringing closure to this surprisingly entertaining legal battle. Until then, we can only imagine Tagore sipping chai and chuckling at the whole affair from up above. Stay tuned for updates – this is one judgment you don't want to miss!
normalised: The court will announce its verdict on first december two thousand and twenty four, hopefully bringing closure to this surprisingly entertaining legal battle. Until then, we can only imagine Tagore sipping chai and chuckling at the whole affair from up above. Stay tuned for updates - this is one judgment you don't want to miss!
